title: COVID-19 bill revives cut in nursing aide training
summary:
A reduction in training requirements for certified nursing assistants (CNA) that Gov.
Language in AB-1038 reduces the minimum number of training hours for CNAs from 120 hours to 75 — the standard provided under federal law.
CNAs are employed mainly in long-term care facilities such as nursing homes.
Current state regulations set the training standard at 120 hours for licensing in Wisconsin, including 32 hours of clinical experience.
Opponents said that the lower training standard wouldn’t alleviate the workforce shortage in the long-term care industry, and raised the chances of putting inadequately trained CNAs in the field.

(Photo: Elliot Hughes / Milwaukee Journal Sentinel)The U.S. Attorney's Office in Milwaukee announced Wednesday that charges have been filed against 24 alleged members of a violent drug trafficking gang that operated out of the city's Harambee neighborhood.
These firearms were seized by Milwaukee-area law enforcement after executing arrest and search warrants related to the investigation of a violent drug trafficking gang known as the Buffum Meinecke Boys.
"Buffum Meinecke" is a reference to the intersection of North Buffum Street and East Meinecke Avenue, which is about five blocks west of Kilbourn Reservoir Park.
The case is being prosecuted as part of a federal, state and local law enforcement collaboration called Project Safe Neighborhoods to control violent crime in Milwaukee.

title: Reports Didn’t Misrepresent One Man’s Death as Two
summary:
Quick TakeA bogus meme on Facebook suggests that the news media has tried to pass off one man’s death, attributed to complications from COVID-19, as two separate cases.
Full StoryThousands of Facebook users are spreading a false suggestion that two different headlines show that a man’s apparent COVID-19-related death has been reported by the news media as two different cases.
“69-year-old retired Milwaukee police lieutenant died from COVID-19,” reads the left headline, which we found was reported by FOX6 in Milwaukee.
Either way, the viral claim that the news reports have misrepresented one man’s death as two separate cases is undercut simply by reading the reports under the headlines.
The claim feeds into the unsupported theory that the official COVID-19 death toll has been inflated.

"This was a difficult decision, but all parties want to ensure we are doing our part to help prevent the spread of the disease.

Neither can be divided in equal portions like a pie, so simple division doesn't work to reconcile the natural world astronomical calendar and human-created calendar we use to mark time.
There are 92.758 days in spring, 93.651 in summer, 89.842 in autumn and 88.994 days in winter.
Every four centuries, our human-created calendar gets a hard reset so the season changes don't keep creeping earlier and earlier.

title: Macomb's Selfridge base snubbed on F-35 aircraft
summary:

“The Department of the Air Force selected the 115th Fighter Wing and the 187th Fighter Wing as the next Air National Guard locations to receive the F-35A,” Air Force Secretary Barbara Barrett said in a Wednesday statement.
“Putting F-35s at these two bases continues our transition into the next generation of air superiority.”Each F-35 Lightning II fighter jet requires more than 900 pounds of rare-earth materials (Photo: Lockheed Martin)Trump said in late January his administration was giving "strong consideration" to deploying F-35 aircraft to Selfridge Air National Guard Base.
In 2017, the U.S. Air Force announced Selfridge was not selected at that point to host one of the next two units of F-35A fighter aircraft.
The Air Force said then Selfridge and the other two finalists — Gowen Field Air National Guard Base in Idaho and Jacksonville Air Guard Station in Florida — were “reasonable alternatives” but not preferred.

summary:

The state had 9,900 more private-sector jobs last month than it did a year earlier, the department said.

title: The silent minority - Milwaukee’s north side remains deeply troubled

title: Strong December doesn’t stop Wisconsin from having slowest job growth since 2010
authors: Arthur Covers Manufacturing For Biztimes. He Previously Was Managing Editor At The Waukesha Freeman. He Is A Graduate Of Carroll University
Did Graduate Coursework At Marquette. A Native Of Southeastern Wisconsin
He Is Also A Nationally Certified Gymnastics Judge
summary:
The year-over-year increase of 0.33% marks the state’s slowest job growth for a calendar year since 2010.
It is also the slowest 12-month job growth period for Wisconsin since July 2011.
For all of 2019, Wisconsin averaged year-over-year private sector job growth of 0.58%, according to the newly released monthly data, still the worst since 2011.
While Wisconsin’s unemployment rate remains low at 3.4%, it has been trending up in recent months, including a 0.1 percentage point increase from November.
The U.S. unemployment rate, on the other hand, has trended down from 3.9% in December 2018 to 3.5% last month.

title: Wisconsin exports end 2019 down more than $1 billion
authors: Arthur Covers Manufacturing For Biztimes. He Previously Was Managing Editor At The Waukesha Freeman. He Is A Graduate Of Carroll University
Did Graduate Coursework At Marquette. A Native Of Southeastern Wisconsin
He Is Also A Nationally Certified Gymnastics Judge
summary:
For the year, Wisconsin ranked 33rd in the country in terms of export growth and the state dropped from 19th to 22nd in terms of total exports.
Wisconsin’s December exports decline was primarily driven by a $40 million or 15.5% decline in shipments to Mexico, a $35.3 million or 9.4% decline in exports to Europe and a $26.2 or 5.3% decline in sales to Canada.
For the year, U.S. exports of goods decreased by $21.3 billion or 1.3% to $1.67 trillion.
Exports of services, meanwhile, increased $19.7 billion or 2.3% to $846 billion.
Wisconsin’s imports of goods also declined in 2019, dropping 8% or $2.48 billion for the year.

title: Mild start to December, but changes are on the way
summary:
Following a colder than normal November, December has started off on the mild side with the first 4 days averaging 2 degrees above normal.
However, it is December in Wisconsin, and over the next few weeks, the pattern will allow a significant cold spell to affect the long-term forecast.
This cold spell arrives next week, as arctic air becomes dislodged from northern Canada.
The rest of the month, temperatures look to stay closer to average, resembling a “typical December”.
December is Milwaukee’s second snowiest month on average, so the current forecast would be below average.
